Vosloo Andrew J. Swarts * Catalysis and Synthesis Research Group, Focus Area for Chemical Resource Beneficiation, North-West University, 11 Hoffman Street, Potchefstroom 2520, South Africa Catalysis and Synthesis Research Group Focus Area for Chemical Resource Beneficiation North-West University 11 Hoffman Street Potchefstroom 2520 South Africa ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract A catalyst system comprising of pyrazolylpyridineamine/Cu(I)/CsOH is reported. for the hydroxylation of aryl iodides and bromides with moderate to outstanding yields, without the use of an inert atmosphere. A comprehensive parameter optimisation study established optimum component concentrations: [Cu(MeCN)4]BF4 and 2-(1H-pyrazol-1-yl)-N-(pyridine-2-ylmethyl)ethan-1-amine (L01) (2 mol %), substrate (1 mmol), CsOH (4 mmol) and DMSO:H2O (1:1, 3 mL). Monitoring substrate conversion as a function of time revealed an induction period of 90 min, which could be eliminated through the initial in situ formation of the proposed [(L01)Cu-OH] intermediate. Eliminating the induction period resulted in complete conversion within one hour, with turnover numbers exceeding that of the benchmark catalyst system operating at an optimal catalyst loading of 0.05 mol %. Keywords Hydroxylation Pyrazolylpyridineamine ligands Copper catalysis Substrate scope Introduction Phenolic compounds are utilised as intermediates during the synthesis of several natural products and polymeric materials, as well as in the pharmaceutical industry [1]. The Hock and Dow processes were initially used for the preparation of these phenolic compounds [2]. These processes involve the sulphuric acid-mediated decomposition of cumene hydroperoxide (CHP) and the treatment of benzene with a hydroxide base and the acidification of the phenoxide salt, respectively. Some of the drawbacks for these processes involve the low yields and ineffective energy use and therefore alternative methods were developed for the synthesis of these functional phenolic compounds. These methods include the non-oxidative Sandmeyer reaction as well as nucleophilic aromatic substitution. Several limitations are associated with these processes such as harsh reaction conditions, a limited substrate scope, as well as difficulties to obtain the required starting materials [3]. These limitations resulted in the growing demand to develop alternative synthesis methods for these phenolic compounds. One of these methods involves the hydroxylation of aryl halides. A number of varying metal-based catalyst systems have previously been reported for these hydroxylation reactions. Initially the focus was on iridium- and palladium-based catalyst systems to provide a milder and more applicable synthesis route for the conversion of aryl halides [4]. However, several drawbacks were identified for these synthetic routes, which involve the employment of expensive catalysts with air- and moisture-sensitivity as well as high toxicity. Furthermore, these routes involve problems with product selectivity because they also resulted in CO coupling by-product formation. These drawbacks resulted in the development of Cu-based catalyst systems, as a result of their economical attractiveness, low toxicity as well as better selectivity control during the reactions. As such, in the recent years, several Cu-based catalyst systems were reported for the hydroxylation of aryl halides [5]. A variety of ligands have been previously evaluated in Cu-based catalyst systems for the hydroxylation of aryl halides. You and co-workers obtained a conversion of 92 % to p-cresol in 24 h with their CuI/phenanthroline/KOH catalyst system [5a]. Independently, Yang and co-workers obtained a slightly lower conversion of 82 % to p-cresol in 18 h, using their CuI/8-hydroxyquinoline N-oxide/CsOH catalyst system [5b]. Taillefer and co-workers reported a CuI/1,3-diphenylpropane-1,3-dione/CsOH catalyst system which resulted in a conversion of 82 % to p-cresol in 24 h [5c]. Unfortunately, even though excellent conversions were achieved for these catalyst systems, high catalyst loadings (5–10 mol % copper and 10–20 mol % ligand), harsh operating conditions (140 °C) and the need for an inert atmosphere are often required [5a–d,6]. Ma and co-workers decreased the catalyst loading to 2 mol % copper and 4 mol % ligand in the development of their Cu(I)/CsOH catalyst system, in combination with substituted 2-pyridin-2-yl-1H-benzoimidazole and 2-(1H-imidazol-2-yl)pyridine ligands, for the hydroxylation of aryl bromides [7]. The electronic nature of the pyridine ring as well as the availability of a free NH-group within the ligand, are of extreme importance for the success of these reactions [7]. Furthermore, Cazin and co-workers further decreased the catalyst loading to 0.05 mol % for their reported [CuCl(NHC)]/CsOH catalyst system for the hydroxylation of iodobenzene [5e]. They obtained turnover numbers (TON) of 1640 when they perform their reactions at 130 °C, under an inert atmosphere and they also found that the conversions were negatively influenced when a base other than CsOH was used [5e,6]. Unfortunately, not all the above-mentioned drawbacks have been addressed yet. Therefore, the need still exists to develop an alternative Cu-based catalyst system, in combination with a variety of efficient ligands that can operate open to air. We have recently reported a Cu(I)-based catalyst system, using substituted iminopyridine or quinoline ligands and NaOH as base to obtain complete conversion to p-cresol in 3 h, with an increased catalyst loading of 4 mol % [5f]. Unfortunately, the limitations of this catalyst system were tested and it could only be employed for aryl iodides. Recently, pyrazolylpyridineamine ligands, coordinated to a nickel precursor, have been employed in the catalytic oligomerisation and polymerisation of ethylene [8]. This ligand framework has not been exploited in Cu-catalysed hydroxylation reactions. Herein we report the synthesis, characterisation and evaluation of similar pyrazolylpyridineamine ligands, 2-(1H-pyrazol-1-yl)-N-(pyridine-2-ylmethyl)ethan-1-amine (L01), 2-(3,5-dimethyl-1H-pyrazol-1-yl)-N-(pyridine-2-ylmethyl)ethan-1-amine (L02), N-methyl-2-(1H-pyrazol-1-yl)-N-(pyridine-2-ylmethyl)ethan-1-amine (L03) and 2-(3,5-dimethyl-1H-pyrazol-1-yl)-N-methyl-N-(pyridine-2-ylmethyl)ethan-1-amine (L04, Fig. 1 ), in combination with copper, as pre-catalysts for the hydroxylation of aryl halides. The effect of both the optimised reaction conditions and the initial in situ formation of a [(L01)Cu-OH] intermediate on the hydroxylation of 4-iodotoluene to p-cresol were evaluated. Finally, we determined the substrate scope of our catalyst system after the evaluation of aryl iodides and bromides. Results and discussion Synthesis and characterisation of the pyrazolylpyridineamine ligands The pyrazolylpyridineamine ligands (L01-L04) were prepared by the alkylation of substituted and unsubstituted pyrazole derivatives, after which reductive amination (L01 and L02) and methylation of the imines (L03 and L04) were performed. The synthesis of ligand L02 have been reported previously [8], while ligands L01, L03 and L04 are novel. The ligands were obtained as light yellow or yellow-brown oils that display solubility in most organic solvents such as dichloromethane (DCM), dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO), acetonitrile (MeCN), alcohols, as well as water. Furthermore, these ligands can be stored without any precaution due to their stability. Several spectroscopic and analytical techniques were employed to characterise these pyrazolylpyridineamine ligands. FT-IR spectroscopy showed the absorption bands for the secondary (L01) and tertiary (L03 and L04) amines in the range 1551−3303 cm−1, 3383−3394 cm−1 and 2946−2947 cm−1, respectively. Similarly, the 1H NMR spectroscopic analysis of the ligands provided useful information on the structure of all compounds. We observed the secondary amine proton resonance at δ 4.74 ppm, while the tertiary amine (N-CH3) singlet resonance was observed more upfield in the range δ 2.31–2.33 ppm (Fig. S1-S6 in the Supporting Information). The introduction of methyl groups on the pyrazole ring for ligand L04 was observed in the range δ 2.17–2.19 ppm, as a singlet resonance. Furthermore, the 13C{1H} NMR spectroscopic analysis confirmed the substitution of methyl groups on the ethyl-linked N-atom (L03 and L04) and on the pyrazole ring (L04) in the range δ 42.56–42.86 ppm and δ 11.07–13.48 ppm, respectively. The purity of these novel pyrazolylpyridineamine ligands (L01-L04) were confirmed with HRMS (Fig. S7-S10 in the Supporting Information). Optimisation of the (L01)[Cu(MeCN)4]BF4/CsOH catalyst system (Scheme 1) Hydroxylation reactions were carried out employing 4-iodotoluene as model substrate, at previously reported reaction conditions, followed by an acidic workup (Scheme 1 ) [5e,5f]. These reactions were initially evaluated using the Radley’s carousel reactor, to ensure the same reaction conditions for multiple reactions, but the obtained results were not reproducible. A white solid sublimed in the cooled area of the reaction tube with concomitant loss of activity. Similar observations of sublimation were previously reported by Ma and co-workers [9]. Repeating the reactions in a small reactor flask (5 mL) in an oil bath circumvented the reproducibility issues. As a point of departure we evaluated different catalyst loadings (Cu:L) on the hydroxylation of 4-iodotoluene, using the reduced pyrazolylpyridineamine ligand (L01), in combination with [Cu(MeCN)4]BF4, under previously reported reaction conditions [5e,5f]. The copper precursor and ligand were stirred for 30 min to allow the in situ formation of the pre-catalyst before the addition of the substrate and hydroxide base. Excellent conversions were observed with a catalyst loading of 2 and 4 mol %, even at a decreased reaction time of 6 h (Table 1 , Entries 1-3). When the catalyst loading was decreased to 1 and 0.5 mol %, significantly lower conversions were obtained (Table 1, Entries 4-5). As such, an optimal catalyst loading of 2 mol % was identified for our catalyst system. Next, we evaluated various pyrazolylpyridineamine ligands, bearing either a hydrogen or methyl group on the pyrazole ring as well as on the ethyl-linked N-atom, L01-L04, in the hydroxylation of 4-iodotoluene (Table 1, Entries 6-11 and Fig. S11 in the Supporting Information). The observed activity, expressed as the conversion of 4-iodotoluene to p-cresol, highlights the fact that the methyl groups on the pyrazole ring has a pronounced effect on the success of the hydroxylation reaction, than the substituents on the ethyl-linked N-atom (Table 1 and Figure S11 in the Supporting Information). Comparable conversions were obtained for the unsubstituted pyrazole-based ligands after 24 h, but a slight difference was observed at a decreased reaction time of 6 h (L01 and L02, Table 1, Entries 2–3 and 6-7). However, the introduction of methyl groups on the pyrazole ring resulted in lower conversions to p-cresol, irrespective of the reaction time (L03 and L04, Table 1, Entries 8-11). The hydroxylation reaction was also performed without a ligand and a conversion of 11 % to the corresponding p-cresol was found (Table 1, Entry 12). Other groups also highlighted the importance of a ligand for successful hydroxylation reactions [5d,10]. The varying reactivity may be due to the availability of a free NH-group within the ligand and the ability to remove the proton during the hydroxylation reaction. Similar observations was reported by Ma and co-workers [7]. Furthermore, the steric and electronic effects of the methyl groups on the pyrazole ring also resulted in lower conversions. These methyl groups hinder the approach of the aryl halide substrate during the formation of the appropriate Cu-based active intermediate. Furthermore, the methyl groups also resulted in a lower electrophilicity of the copper metal centre due to the electron-donating ability of the methyl groups [11]. The above-mentioned conversion results are comparable with that obtained in previous literature reports, using higher catalyst loadings of up to 20 mol % [5a–d,5f]. However, even though our catalyst system displayed excellent conversions at relatively low catalyst loadings and shorter reaction times, it could still not be compared to the activity reported by Cazin and co-workers where they observed TON values of 1640 [5e]. They employed an inert atmosphere for the hydroxylation reactions, while our reactions were performed in a closed reactor tube, under ambient air, to prevent evaporation of the solvent at high temperatures. In conclusion, both ligands L01 and L02 could be used for the successful hydroxylation of 4-iodotoluene in a reaction time of 6 h and were employed in further optimisation studies. Next, we evaluated the effect of varying hydroxide bases on the hydroxylation of 4-iodotoluene to p-cresol, using either ligand L01 or L02 (Table 2 and Figure S12 in the Supporting Information). Sodium hydroxide (NaOH) as base resulted in conversions of 86 % and 62 % respectively (Table 2, Entries 1 and 4). When the base was replaced with potassium hydroxide (KOH), conversions of 100 % and 66 % were obtained respectively (Table 2, Entries 2 and 5), while the employmentof cesium hydroxide (CsOH) as base resulted in similar conversions of 100 % and 98 % respectively (Table 2, Entries 3 and 6). As a result, both KOH and CsOH displayed excellent conversions, using ligand L01, while for ligand L02, only the reaction with CsOH displayed complete conversion. The next step was to evaluate the amount of base (KOH and CsOH) on the hydroxylation of 4-iodotoluene, using either ligand L01 or L02 (Table 3 and Figure S13 in the Supporting Information). The reaction time for these reactions was 4 h, instead of the optimised 6 h to determine whether the amount of base has an influence on the hydroxylation of 4-iodotoluene. Similar conversions to p-cresol were obtained with the standard reaction conditions of 4 mmol CsOH or KOH as base when either ligand L01 or L02 was employed (Table 3, Entries 1-4). With a decrease in the amount of CsOH to 2 mmol, slightly lower conversions were obtained (Table 3, Entries 5-6), while a significant decrease in the conversion to p-cresol was observed, using KOH as base (Table 3, Entries 7-8). Finally, the hydroxylation of 4-iodotoluene was also performed in the absence of base, which resulted in low conversions of between 2–12 % for ligands L01 and L02, respectively (Table 3, Entries 9-10). In conclusion, the introduction of CsOH as base resulted in better conversions to p-cresol for both ligands, while only average conversions were obtained for ligand L02 when KOH was employed. Even though KOH is a less expensive base than CsOH, the conversion to p-cresol was slightly lower. Previous reports found that the selectivity towards the phenolic product decreases when a weaker base such as KOH was employed [2,5c,12]. The conversion of 4-iodotoluene was possible with a lower amount of base, but it was decided that ligand L01 and CsOH (4 mmol) as base were optimal. Lastly, we evaluated different Cu(I)/(II)-precursors, using ligand L01, for the hydroxylation of 4-iodotoluene (Table 4 and Figure S14 in the Supporting Information). These reactions were allowed to run for 4 h, instead of the optimised 6 h, to determine the effect of both the counter anion as well as the oxidation state of the varying Cu-precursors. We evaluated Cu(I)-precursors containing non-coordinating anions such as tetrafluoroborate (BF4 −) or triflate (OTf), which resulted in higher conversions than those with the coordinating anions such as copper(I) chloride (CuCl) or -bromide (CuBr, Table 4, Entries 1–2 and 4-5). An exception, however, was found when the non-coordinating anion was replaced with the hexafluorophosphate anion (PF6 −), because almost no conversion to p-cresol was obtained (Table 4, Entry 3). This Cu-precursor has never been used in previous hydroxylation reactions and this observation is in contrast with our previous findings where [Cu(MeCN)4]PF6 was employed as Cu-precursor in aerobic alcohol oxidation reactions [11d]. It is still unclear why [Cu(MeCN)4]PF6, as Cu-precursor, resulted in low conversions to p-cresol. The use of Cu(II)-precursors (Table 4, Entries 6-10) displayed comparable conversions, relative to the Cu(I)-precursors. Interestingly, relatively good conversions to p-cresol were obtained for the Cu(II)-precursors which are hydrates (Table 6, Entries 8-10). Lastly, the hydroxylation of 4-iodotoluene without a Cu-precursor resulted in no conversion to p-cresol (Table 6, Entry 11). We observe a higher catalytic activity, relative to previously reported results, which may be a result of the Cu-precursor′s nature. Studies on the nature of the counter anion have been previously reported for Cu-based alcohol oxidation reactions [11d,13]. Several previously reported catalyst systems focused on a Cu-precursor with a coordinating counter anion, whereas our focus rather shifts to a Cu-precursor with the non-coordinating anion, BF4 −. The faster dissociation of the non-coordinating anions, relative to the coordinating anions, facilitate the approach of the aryl halide to coordinate with the copper centre. This leads to the promotion of the oxidative addition steps, which supports the findings of Mketo and co-workers [5f]. Even though a Cu(II)-precursor resulted in relatively good conversions, it is clear that a Cu(I)-precursor is needed for these reactions and [Cu(MeCN)4]BF4 was found to be the optimal Cu-precursor for the hydroxylation of aryl halides. In conclusion, our alternative Cu-based catalyst system could be fully optimised for the hydroxylation of 4-iodotoluene to p-cresol (Scheme 2 ). Effect of the presence of the in situ formed Cu-intermediate After our optimisation studies, we evaluated the hydroxylation of 4-iodotoluene over time (Fig. 2 and Table S1 in the Supporting Information). Separate hydroxylation reactions were employed and analysed after an acidic workup, for the varying reaction times. Initially an induction period of approximately 90 min was observed after which the conversion to p-cresol started to increase until a plateau was reached between 4 and 6 h. The induction period is possibly due to the absence of an active Cu-based intermediate that can initiate the hydroxylation reactions. Llobet and co-workers reported a Cu-based catalyst system for water oxidation, using tetradentate amidate acyclic ligands and their results suggested the formation of [(L1)Cu(OH)] species during the reaction [14]. Similarly, the formation of Cu-hydroxo intermediates during the hydroxylation of aryl halides have been previously proposed [5e,12,15]. In 2012, Cazin and co-workers proposed the formation of [Cu(OH)-(NHC)] as an active intermediate, which was evaluated using a well-defined [Cu(OH)(IPr)] (IPr = N,N′-bis-[2,6-(di-iso-propyl)phenyl]imidazole-2-ylidene) complex, but the reaction resulted in lower conversions to the phenolic products [5e]. Separately, in 2013, Jutand and co-workers used cyclic voltammetry (CV) studies for the characterisation of the proposed Cu-OH key intermediate [12]. They proposed that this key intermediate will react with the aryl halide substrate. However, the effect of this Cu-OH key intermediate on the hydroxylation reaction, as well as when the intermediate is formed during the reaction are still unknown. Computational and electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) studies have shown that the pH of the reaction determines the type of Cu-OH intermediates that might form during the reaction [15b,16]. At a pH below 8, only [LCu(II)-OH2] is present, while [LCu(II)-OH2], [LCu(II)-OH] and the [LCu(II)-OH] dimer are present in the pH range of 8–10. Furthermore, with the pH above 10, a combination of [LCu(II)-OH] and the [LCu(II)-OH] dimer are observed. However, previous groups highlighted the formation of an off-cycle Cu-hydroxide dimeric species as a catalyst deactivator [17]. The pH of the hydroxylation reaction, using our optimised Cu-based catalyst system, was between 15 and 16, which resulted in the possibility that both [LCu(II)-OH] and the [LCu(II)-OH] dimer are present within the system. However, due to the possible deactivating ability of the dimeric species, we assume that only the monomeric [LCu(II)-OH] intermediate is present during the hydroxylation reaction. To our knowledge, however, the initial in situ synthesis and evaluation of the effect of the [(L01)Cu-OH] intermediate on the hydroxylation reaction has not been investigated previously. We postulate that the initial presence of the [(L01)Cu-OH] intermediate, instead of the formation thereof during the reaction, would result in either a shorter/no induction period and thereby speed up the reaction time for complete conversion to the corresponding phenolic products. A similar observation in alcohol oxidation was reported by Stahl and co-workers where they used a hydroxide containing intermediate, [(bpy)Cu(OH)]2(OTf)2 which was dissociated to the monomeric (bpy)Cu(II)(OH)(OTf) species, to eliminate the induction period during the reaction [17e]. Additional experiments were employed to determine whether the initial in situ formation of the [(L01)Cu-OH] intermediate has an influence on the activity of the hydroxylation reactions, as a function of time (Fig. 2 and Table S2 in the Supporting Information). We found that the induction period of these reactions was eliminated, because conversion to p-cresol was observed after only 23 min. Complete conversion to p-cresol was obtained in approximately 1 h. As a result, higher conversions were observed in a shorter reaction time for the latter reaction conditions relative to those where the optimised reaction conditions were employed. In conclusion, we now have experimental evidence for the effect of the initial in situ formed [(L01)Cu-OH] intermediate on the hydroxylation of 4-iodotoluene. Similar hydroxylation reactions, with the initial presence of the [(L01)Cu-OH] intermediate, were performed to determine whether conversions to p-cresol were possible at lower catalyst loadings due to the elimination of the induction period (Table 5 ). Conversions to p-cresol of 98 % and 8 % to p-cresol and TON values of 1952 and 819 were obtained respectively for our catalyst system for a reaction time of 24 h (Table 5, Entries 1 and 2). As such, with the initial in situ synthesis of the [(L01)Cu-OH] intermediate, we were not only able to eliminate the induction period of the reaction, but we could also improve on our previous results obtained for the varying catalyst loadings during the optimisation of our catalyst system (Table 1, Entries 1–5). Furthermore, these results were also compared with the benchmark catalyst system, reported by Cazin and co-workers, where they obtained a conversion of 82 % to p-cresol with an optimal catalyst loading of 0.05 mol %, under an inert atmosphere (Table 5, Entry 3) [5e]. In conclusion, we could improve on the conversion results and TON values as reported for the benchmark catalyst system. To our knowledge, these conversions to p-cresol are currently the highest and most promising results, especially when employing a low catalyst loading and in the absence of an inert atmosphere. Substrate scope of the (L01)[Cu(MeCN)4]BF4/CsOH catalyst system Our optimised Cu-based catalyst system were employed in the evaluation of the substrate scope for the hydroxylation reactions (Scheme 2). Table 6 summarise the capability of our catalyst system to convert a variety of aryl iodides with moderate to outstanding yields of the phenolic compounds, ranging from 70 % to 96 %. These aryl iodides include those with electron-donating substituents (Table 6, Entries 1-3) as well as those with electron-withdrawing substituents (Table 6, Entries 4-6). The activity of the hydroxylation reaction was enhanced when substrates bearing electron-withdrawing substituents were used. Our Cu-based catalyst system was tolerant towards a great selection of functional groups including methyl, alkoxy, acetyl, nitro and alcohol substituents in the absence of an inert atmosphere. By comparing our results with those previously reported, it is evident that we could improve on the yields, decrease the catalyst loadings and/or reduce the reaction times [5a–c,5e,5f,18]. The electronic nature of the para-positioned substituents had no significant effect on the hydroxylation reaction. Furthermore, even though a longer reaction time was required for the successful conversion of the sterically hindered 2-iodotoluene to o-cresol (Table 6, Entry 7), we were still unable to convert 2-iodoaniline to the corresponding phenolic compound (Table 6, Entry 8). This observation is due to the regioselective conversion of iodoaniline to the corresponding phenazine product. Gendrineau and co-workers reported a Pd-based catalyst system for the synthesis of substituted phenazines, by employing phosphine ligands [19]. We were also capable of converting a variety of less reactive electrophiles such as the aryl bromides (Table 7 , Entries 1-4). The products of these reactions are important in industrial applications. We were able to convert 2-bromophenol, a substrate that was not previously evaluated, to catechol with an isolated yield of 68 % (Table 7, Entry 3). Several previous reports confirmed the formation of biaryl ether by-products during the hydroxylation reactions, when performed in neat water [2,5b,5c]. However, Mketo and co-workers highlighted the excellent chemoselectivity of their catalyst system for hydroxylation reactions without the formation of any biaryl ether by-products [5f]. With the exception of 2-bromophenol, we did not observe the formation of by-products during the hydroxylation of aryl halides. A limitation of our catalyst system is the inability to successfully convert the sterically hindered 2-bromoanisole during the hydroxylation reaction and a complex mixture of products were generated (Table 7, Entry 5). In conclusion, the conversions to the corresponding phenolic products were slightly higher for the aryl iodides relative to those employing aryl bromides. Unfortunately, we were not able to use our catalyst system for the hydroxylation of aryl chloride and fluoride substrates (Table 7, Entries 6-8). Conclusions We have successfully synthesised and characterised different novel pyrazolylpyridineamine ligands (Fig. 1). These ligands, in combination with [Cu(MeCN)4]BF4 and CsOH, were evaluated as pre-catalysts in the hydroxylation of a variety of aryl halides to their corresponding phenolic products, operating under ambient reaction conditions. The optimisation of the (L01)/[Cu(MeCN)4]BF4/CsOH catalyst system was accomplished by evaluating the catalyst loading, different pyrazolylpyridineamine ligands, hydroxide bases and Cu(I)/(II)-precursors on the hydroxylation of 4-iodotoluene to p-cresol. The evaluation of the optimised reaction conditions allowed us to identify an induction period of 90 min. With the initial in situ formation of the proposed [(L01)Cu-OH] intermediate, we could eliminate the induction period and thereby speed up the hydroxylation reaction for complete conversion within 1 h. Furthermore, we could also improve on the conversion results of the benchmark catalyst system at an optimal catalyst loading of 0.05 mol % Lastly, the evaluation of the substrate scope of our Cu-based catalyst system revealed that it we were able to convert a variety of aryl iodide and bromide substrates with moderate to outstanding conversions. Unfortunately, we were not able to use our catalyst system for the hydroxylation of aryl chloride and fluoride substrates. Future work is focused on the identification and isolation of key Cu-based intermediates as well as the evaluation of the mechanistic pathway for these hydroxylation reactions. Experimental section General considerations The commercially available reagents were obtained from Sigma-Aldrich and/or Merck and used as received. A literature procedure was employed for the synthesis of 2-(3,5-dimethyl-1H-pyrazol-1-yl)-N-(pyridine-2-ylmethyl)ethan-1-amine (L02) [8]. NMR [1H and 13C{1H}] spectra were recorded on a Bruker Ultrashield Plus spectrometer at 600 MHz and 150 MHz respectively. The chemical shifts (δ) are shown in parts per million (ppm) and referenced by using the residual protons of the deuterated solvent signal [20]. The coupling constants are reported in Hz. IR spectra were recorded on neat oils with a BrukerAlpha-P range FT-IR spectrometer, equipped with an ATR accessory. APCI (positive ion mode) spectra were recorded on a Bruker microTOF-Q II spectrometer. GC analyses were performed on an Agilent 6890 Series GC system with a HP 5 column and samples (0.2 mL) were analysed with biphenyl as internal standard. GCMS analyses were performed on an Agilent 6890 N Series GC system with a mass selective (5973) detector and a HP 5-MSUI column and samples were analysed in the absence of an internal standard to confirm complete conversion. Duplicate hydroxylation reactions were performed to obtain average conversions and standard deviations. Complete phenol conversion was identified at the end of the hydroxylation reaction, after acidic workup and extraction with EtOAc. Synthesis of the pyrazolylpyridineamine ligands (L01, L03 and L04) The synthesis methods for the initial primary amine and imine precursors for the pyrazolylpyridineamine ligands, are described in the Supporting Information. -(1H-pyrazol-1-yl)-N-(pyridine-2-ylmethyl)ethan-1-amine (L01) A modified method was used for the reduction of the pyrazole-based ligands [21]. The pyrazole imine (0.17 g, 1.5 mmol) was dissolved in ethanol (6 mL) and cooled down in an ice bath for 30 min. Separately, NaBH4 (0.29 g, 7.66 mmol in 1 ml ethanol), was added to a 100 ml round-bottom flask which was also cooled down in the ice bath. After the allotted time, NaBH4 was added to the pyrazole imine whereafter the reaction mixture was stirred for 1 h and then refluxed for another hour. The reaction mixture was refluxed to remove the solvent before DCM (20 mL) was added. The organic phase was washed with water (2 × 5 mL), dried over anhydrous Na2SO4 and filtered. The solvent was removed in vacuo to obtain the product as a dark brown oil. Yield: 82 mg (97 %). 1H NMR (600 MHz, CDCl3): δ 8.50 (d, J =4.6 Hz, 1H, HAr), 7.60 (t, J = 7.7, 1.4 Hz, 1H, HAr), 7.50 (s, 1H, HAr), 7.43 (d, J =1.8 Hz, 1H, HAr), 7.25-7.22 (t, 1H, HAr), 7.13 (t, J = 7.2, 5.2 Hz, 1H, HAr), 6.23 (s, 1H, HAr), 4.74 (s, 1H, NH), 4.26 (t, J =6.0 Hz, 2H, NCH 2CH2), 3.86 (s, 2H, NHCH 2), 3.08 (t, J =6.0 Hz, 2H, NCH2CH 2). 13C{1H} NMR (150 MHz, CDCl3): δ 159.37 (CAr), δ 149.30 (CAr), δ 139.62 (CAr), δ 136.61 (CAr), δ 129.75 (CAr), δ 122.23 (CAr), δ 122.08 (CAr), δ 105.45 (CAr), δ 54.75 (NHCH2), δ 52.15 (NCH2CH2), δ 49.04 (NCH2 CH2) (Figures S1 and S2 in the Supporting Information). N-methyl-2-(1H-pyrazol-1-yl)-N-(pyridine-2-ylmethyl)ethan-1-amine (L03) A modified method was used for the methylation of the secondary pyrazolylamine ligands [21]. The secondary pyrazolylamine ligand (0.10 g, 0.5 mmol) was dissolved in MeCN (5 mL) in a 100 ml round bottom flask. The solution was allowed to stir during the addition of 100 % formaldehyde (0.436 g, 5.54 mmol) and glacial acetic acid (0.75 mL) after which it was stirred for 30 min. NaBH4 (0.08 g, 2.1 mmol) was slowly added to the reaction mixture and stirred for 72 h at room temperature. The MeCN solvent was removed in vacuo and 2 M KOH was added to increase the pH above 10. The reaction mixture was extracted with DCM (3 × 10 mL) and dried over anhydrous Na2SO4. The solvent was removed in vacuo to obtain the product as a dark brown oil. The same synthesis method was used for ligand L04, as described in the Supporting Information. Optimisation of our Cu-based catalyst system The optimisation of our catalyst system were performed by varying the catalyst loading (Cu:L), reaction time, Cu(I)/Cu(II)-precursors, pyrazolylpyridineamine ligands and bases in the hydroxylation of 4-iodotoluene. A solution of the Cu-precursor ([Cu(MeCN)4]BF4, [Cu(MeCN)4]OTf, [Cu(MeCN)4]PF6, CuCl, CuBr, Cu(BF4)2·xH2O, Cu(OTf)2, CuCl2·2H2O, CuSO4·5H2O and CuOAc·2H2O, x mol %, in 0.5 ml DMSO) and ligand (L01-L04, x mol %, in 0.5 ml DMSO) were stirred in a small, closed reactor flask for 30 min at room temperature. 4-iodotoluene (1 mmol, in 0.5 ml DMSO) and hydroxide base (NaOH, KOH or CsOH (4 mmol, in 1.5 ml H2O) were added to the green complex mixture whereafter the reaction was stirred for 6 or 24 h at 120 ± 2 °C. During the reaction, it changed from dark green to a milky yellow colour and then again to a clear yellow-orange colour. After the allotted time, the mixture was cooled down and acidified with 0.1 M hydrochloric acid (HCl, 25 mL). The acidified solvent was extracted with EtOAc (10 mL) and the organic layer was dried over anhydrous sodium sulfate (Na2SO4). After the solvent was filtered through a syringe filter, a sample (0.2 mL) was analysed by GC with biphenyl (50 μL) as internal standard. Effect of the presence of the in situ formed Cu-intermediate The hydroxylation of 4-iodotoluene was evaluated over a range of reaction times (0.5–6 h), using either the optimised reaction conditions or the initial in situ formation of the [(L01)Cu-OH] intermediate. The alternative reaction conditions involve: A solution of [Cu(MeCN)4]BF4 (2 mol %, in 0.5 ml DMSO), ligand L01 (2 mol %, in 0.5 ml DMSO) and CsOH (4 mmol, in 1.5 ml H2O) were stirred in a small reactor flask, for 5 min at 120 ± 2 °C, open to air. 4-iodotoluene (1 mmol, in 0.5 ml DMSO) was added to the milky orange complex mixture, closed and the reaction was stirred for 0.5–6 h at 120 ± 2 °C. The reaction mixture changed to a milky light yellow and later a clear light grey colour. After the allotted time, the mixture was cooled down to room temperature and then acidified with 0.1 M HCl (25 mL). The acidified solvent was extracted with EtOAc (10 mL) and the organic layer was dried over Na2SO4. After the solvent was filtered through a syringe filter, a sample (0.2 mL) was analysed by GC with biphenyl (50 μL) as internal standard. These reactions were performed in duplicate and the varying reaction times, conversions (%) and the standard deviations are summarised in the Supporting Information, Tables S1 and S2. Evaluation of catalyst loading: alternative reaction conditions The same method as mentioned above was used, but the catalyst loading was varied between 0.01 and 0.05 mol %. The reaction mixture was acidified, extracted with EtOAc and filtered through a silica plug. A sample (0.2 mL) was analysed by GC with biphenyl (50 μL) as internal standard. Evaluation of the substrate scope and limitations for the hydroxylation reactions A solution of the [Cu(MeCN)4]BF4 (2 mol %, in 0.5 ml DMSO) and ligand L01 (2 mol %, in 0.5 ml DMSO) was stirred in a small reactor flask, for 30 min at room temperature. Aryl halides (different aryl iodides and bromides, 1 mmol, in 0.5 ml DMSO) and CsOH (4 mmol, in 1.5 ml H2O) were added to the green complex mixture and the reaction was stirred for varying reaction times at 120 ± 2 °C. The reaction mixture changed from dark green to a yellow milky colour and then a clear yellow-orange colour. After the allotted time, the mixture was cooled down and acidified with 0.1 M HCl (25 mL). Extraction was done with EtOAc (3 × 10 mL) and the organic layer was dried over Na2SO4, filtered and the solvent was removed in vacuo. The phenolic product was flushed through a silica plug, using petroleum spirit/EtOAc as eluent, to remove residual DMSO. coredata.dc:description: A catalyst system comprising of pyrazolylpyridineamine/Cu(I)/CsOH is reported. for the hydroxylation of aryl iodides and bromides with moderate to outstanding yields, without the use of an inert atmosphere. A comprehensive parameter optimisation study established optimum component concentrations: [Cu(MeCN)4]BF4 and 2-(1H-pyrazol-1-yl)-N-(pyridine-2-ylmethyl)ethan-1-amine (L01) (2 mol %), substrate (1 mmol), CsOH (4 mmol) and DMSO:H2O (1:1, 3 mL). Monitoring substrate conversion as a function of time revealed an induction period of 90 min, which could be eliminated through the initial in situ formation of the proposed [(L01)Cu-OH] intermediate. Eliminating the induction period resulted in complete conversion within one hour, with turnover numbers exceeding that of the benchmark catalyst system operating at an optimal catalyst loading of 0.05 mol %.
coredata.dc:title: The development of a Cu(I)/pyrazolylpyridineamine catalyst system for the hydroxylation of aryl halides
